content: The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the preparation of a National Park System Plan by the Secretary of the Interior. The plan will define the mission and role of the National Park Service in preserving natural and cultural heritage, establish criteria for including resources in the system, and identify adequate representation of resource types. The National Park System Plan, mandated by the National Park System Reform Act of 1994, aims to identify aspects of the national heritage not currently represented in the system and prioritize themes and resources to be added. It also outlines the role of the National Park Service in preserving natural and cultural resources and providing outdoor recreation opportunities. The National Park System Plan, as mandated by the National Park System Reform Act of 1994, includes defining units of the system, consulting with various stakeholders, and transmitting the plan to Congress within a specified timeframe. The curr_chunk is about representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to consider alternative management options, such as partnerships with states, local governments, and the private sector. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated based on factors like duplication, lack of significance, and cost. The Secretary will review the National Park System for potential changes in management, considering factors like cost, visitor accessibility, resource protection, and collaboration. Recommendations will be made for areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated, with alternatives proposed to ensure resource protection and public access. Collaboration with other Federal land managing entities will be part of the consultation process. The Secretary will consult with various stakeholders and transmit a report to Congress containing recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management within the National Park System. The Secretary will consult stakeholders and submit a report to Congress with recommendations for changes in National Park Service management within the National Park System, including alternative management options. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units and suggest modifications or terminations to the management of specific areas. The Commission will consider factors from section 102(a)(2) and present alternative solutions to the Natural Resources Committee of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate within one year of its establishment. The Commission shall suggest alternative management for listed areas by entities other than the National Park Service. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management must be identified for areas of national significance before inclusion on the list. The Commission will consult with various agencies and organizations, including opportunities for public review and comment. Membership of the Commission consists of 7 members with substantial familiarity with the subject matter. The Commission consists of 7 members with expertise in the National Park System. Members are appointed by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. The Commission elects a chair from its members, vacancies do not affect its functions, and a simple majority constitutes a quorum. The Commission, consisting of 7 members with expertise in the National Park System, requires a simple majority for a quorum. Meetings are held quarterly or as called by the chair or majority members. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Commission terminates 90 days after submitting the report to Congress. Staff can be hired, limited by the National Park Service. The Commission can hire staff to carry out responsibilities, with limitations on the number of National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can also procure temporary services and hold public hearings as needed. The Commission has the authority to make bylaws, rules, and regulations, use the United States mails, and request information from the Secretary relevant to its duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include general authority, remove certain sentences, authorize appropriations, and add a new subsection for studies of potential park additions. The Secretary must annually submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. Consideration must be given to areas with national significance, suitability, and feasibility, as well as themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the National Park System. No study for potential inclusion in the National Park System can be initiated without proper consideration. The Secretary must complete the study for each area proposed for inclusion in the National Park System, with specific authorization required from Congress. The National Park Service has the authority to conduct preliminary assessments, gather data, provide assistance, and update studies for areas requiring less than $25,000 in expenditure. This section does not apply to studies for potential addition to the national wild and scenic rivers system or national trails system. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusions within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Public involvement, including meetings and notifications, is required. Considerations include national significance of resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and suitability for addition to the system. Each study for potential National Park System inclusions must consider factors such as resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public support. It should also assess whether National Park Service management or alternative protection is more suitable for the area. The Director of the National Park Service must identify the most effective way to protect resources and provide public enjoyment. A recommendation for the preferred management option will be included in each study submitted to Congress. Additionally, the Secretary must provide a list of areas studied for potential National Park System inclusions at the beginning of each calendar year. The Secretary must prioritize areas for addition to the National Park System based on threats to resource values and cost factors. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994.
